trans-unit.source: Defines an area where you can arrange child elements either horizontally or vertically, relative to each other.
A <xref:System.Windows.Controls.DockPanel> contains a collection of <xref:System.Windows.UIElement> objects, which are in the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.Panel.Children%2A> property.
The <xref:System.Windows.Controls.DockPanel.SetDock%2A> method changes the position of an element relative to other elements within the same container.
Alignment properties, such as <xref:System.Windows.FrameworkElement.HorizontalAlignment%2A>, change the position of an element relative to its parent element.

If you set the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.DockPanel.LastChildFill%2A> property to `true`, which is the default setting, the last child element of a <xref:System.Windows.Controls.DockPanel> always fills the remaining space, regardless of any other dock value that you set on the last child element.

To dock a child element in another direction, you must set the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.DockPanel.LastChildFill%2A> property to `false` and must also specify an explicit dock direction for the last child element.
Panel elements do not receive focus by default.
To compel a panel element to receive focus, set the <xref:System.Windows.UIElement.Focusable%2A> property to `true`.

**Note:** The position of child elements of a <xref:System.Windows.Controls.DockPanel> on the screen is determined by the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.DockPanel.Dock%2A> property of the respective child elements *and* the relative order of those child elements under the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.DockPanel>.

Therefore, a set of child elements with the same Dock property values can be positioned differently on the screen depending on the order of these children under the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.DockPanel>.

Child ordering effects positioning because the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.DockPanel> iterates through its child elements in order, setting the position of each element depending on remaining space.
Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Windows.Controls.DockPanel"></xref> class.
Arranges the content (child elements) of a <xref href="System.Windows.Controls.DockPanel"></xref> element.
The <xref href="System.Windows.Size"></xref> this element uses to arrange its child elements.
The <xref href="System.Windows.Size"></xref> that represents the arranged size of this <xref href="System.Windows.Controls.DockPanel"></xref> element.
Identifies the <xref href="System.Windows.Controls.DockPanel.Dock"></xref> attached property.
Gets the value of the <xref href="System.Windows.Controls.DockPanel.Dock"></xref> attached property for a specified <xref href="System.Windows.UIElement"></xref>.
The element from which the property value is read.
The <xref href="System.Windows.Controls.DockPanel.Dock"></xref> property value for the element.
Gets or sets a value that indicates whether the last child element within a <xref href="System.Windows.Controls.DockPanel"></xref> stretches to fill the remaining available space.

If you set the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.DockPanel.LastChildFill%2A> property to `true`, which is the default setting, the last child element of a <xref:System.Windows.Controls.DockPanel> always fills the remaining space, regardless of any other dock value that you set on the last child element.

To dock a child element in another direction, you must set the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.DockPanel.LastChildFill%2A> property to `false` and must also specify an explicit dock direction on the last child element.
Dependency Property Information
Identifier field
Metadata properties set to `true`
`true` if the last child element stretches to fill the remaining space; otherwise `false`.
The default value is `true`.
Identifies the <xref href="System.Windows.Controls.DockPanel.LastChildFill"></xref> dependency property.

Measures the child elements of a <xref href="System.Windows.Controls.DockPanel"></xref> prior to arranging them during the <xref href="System.Windows.Controls.DockPanel.ArrangeOverride(System.Windows.Size)"></xref> pass.
A <xref:System.Windows.Controls.DockPanel> determines its size by analyzing the sizing properties and <xref:System.Windows.Controls.DockPanel.Dock%2A> property value of its child elements.
A child element can occupy all the space on the side where it is docked.
Child elements that are docked to the `Left` or `Right` are granted all the vertical space for their entire width.
Child elements that are docked to the `Top` or `Bottom` are granted all the horizontal space for their entire height.
A maximum <xref href="System.Windows.Size"></xref> to not exceed.
A <xref href="System.Windows.Size"></xref> that represents the element size you want.
Sets the value of the <xref href="System.Windows.Controls.DockPanel.Dock"></xref> attached property to a specified element.
The <xref:System.Windows.Controls.DockPanel.SetDock%2A> method changes the position of a child element relative to other child elements within the same container.
Alignment properties, such as <xref:System.Windows.FrameworkElement.HorizontalAlignment%2A>, change the position of a child element relative to its parent element.
The element to which the attached property is written.
The needed <xref href="System.Windows.Controls.Dock"></xref> value.
